prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: L1551 IRS 5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 90 au at the distance of L1551 IRS 5, enough to resolve the envelope, whose size is about 15 arcsec in 13CO (see again the PhD dissertation of Yokogawa). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For L1551 IRS 5, we based our sensitivity calculations on the 13CO(1-0) flux and size measurements from the PhD dissertation of Sozo Yokogawa (2003). The 13CO line is bright enough that an rms of 15 mJy per beam per resolution element will ensure a S/N above 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 9 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be enough to detect the 1.3 mm continuum emission as well.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Haro 5a IRS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 300 au at the distance of Haro 5a IRS. This will be enough to resolve a typical envelope of about 10000 au or 22 arcsec. To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For Haro 5a IRS, we based our sensitivity calculations on our APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation. Based on our experience with Bran 76, the 2-1 line will be equally bright or only slightly fainter. The size of the object is not known, we assume typical envelope sizes at the distance of Orion. The 13CO line is bright enough that an rms of 15 mJy per beam per resolution element will ensure a S/N above 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 8 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be about 60 microJy. We have no information about the continuum flux of the target. If it is at least 0.18 mJy, we will have at least a 3-sigma detection (but we note that detecting the continuum is not the primary goal of the proposal).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AR 6A/6B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 520 au at the distance of AR 6A/6B. This will be enough to resolve both the binary (separation is 2.8 arcsec, Aspin & Reipurth 2003) and the envelope, whose size is about 40 arcsec (Gramajo et al. 2014). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For AR 6A/6B, we based our sensitivity calculations on our APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation. Based on our experience with Bran 76, the 2-1 line will be equally bright or only slightly fainter. The size of the objects' envelope was taken from the model fitting of Gramajo et al. (2014). The 13CO line is bright enough that an rms of 15 mJy per beam per resolution element will ensure a S/N above 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 9 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be about 60 micro-Jy. We have no information about the continuum flux of these objects. If it is at least 0.18 mJy, we will have at least a 3-sigma detection (but we note that detecting the continuum is not the primary goal of the proposal).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: V900 Mon, Z CMa
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of two close-by sources in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 715 au at the distance of V900 Mon and Z CMa, enough to resolve the envelope, whose size is about 15 arcsec for V900 Mon and 30 arcsec for Z CMa (Gramajo et al. 2014). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For V900 Mon, we based our sensitivity calculations on our APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation, while for Z CMa, archival APEX 13CO(2-1) data were available. Based on our experience with Bran 76, the 2-1 line will be equally bright or only slightly fainter than the 3-2 transition. The size and the continuum flux of these objects were taken from the model fitting of Gramajo et al. (2014). The 13CO line in both source is bright enough that an rms of 15 mJy per beam per resolution element will ensure a S/N above 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 8 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be enough to detect the 1.3 mm continuum emission only for the innermost, brightest parts of the envelope.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Bran 76
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 1100 au at the distance of Bran 76, enough to resolve the envelope, whose size is about 15 arcsec (Gramajo et al. 2014). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For Bran 76, we have our own APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation, and found archival APEX 13CO(2-1) data as well. The two different transitions are about equally bright. The size and the continuum flux of the object was taken from the model fitting of Gramajo et al. (2014). The 13CO line is among the faintest in our sample, thus we request an rms of 10 mJy per beam per resolution element to ensure a S/N close to 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 17 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be enough to detect the 1.3 mm continuum emission as well.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Parsamian 21
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 260 au at the distance of Parsamian 21, enough to resolve the envelope, whose size is about 35 arcsec (Gramajo et al. 2014). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For Parsamian 21, we based our sensitivity calculations on our APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation. Based on our experience with Bran 76, the 2-1 line will be equally bright or only slightly fainter. The size and the continuum flux of the object was taken from the model fitting of Gramajo et al. (2014). The 13CO line is the faintest in our sample, thus we request an rms of 10 mJy per beam per resolution element to ensure a S/N of about 35. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 19 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be enough to detect the 1.3 mm continuum emission only for the innermost, brightest parts of the envelope.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: OO Ser
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observation of a single source in 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan a simultaneous observation of the J=2-1 line of all three CO isotopologues (12CO, 13CO, and C18O), as well as the 1.3 mm continuum in one science goal. In order to resolve the slow motion of gas in the envelopes, we request 0.04 km/s for the (brightest) 12CO and 0.08 km/s for the other two fainter lines.
The 12m array data rate is slightly higher than the policy value, but this is unavoidable when observing three lines in three FDM windows in one science goal.

We plan a complete homogeneous survey of all targets at a resolution of 0.65 arcsec. This corresponds to 200 au at the distance of OO Ser, enough to resolve the envelope, whose size is about 35 arcsec (Gramajo et al. 2014). To recover the emission from the largest scales, we request ACA data.

For OO Ser, we based our sensitivity calculations on our APEX 13CO(3-2) line observation. Based on our experience with Bran 76, the 2-1 line will be equally bright or only slightly fainter. The size and the continuum flux of the object was taken from the model fitting of Gramajo et al. (2014). The 13CO line is bright enough that an rms of 15 mJy per beam per resolution element will ensure a S/N above 100. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this can be achieved in 8 min. During this time, the continuum sensitivity in the 3.9 GHz aggregate bandwidth will be enough to detect the 1.3 mm continuum emission only for the innermost, brightest parts of the envelope.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: FU Orionis-type stars (FUors) are young stellar objects experiencing large optical outbursts due to highly enhanced accretion from the circumstellar disk onto the star. FUors are often surrounded by envelopes, which have a significant role in the outburst mechanism. Conversely, the subsequent eruptions gradually clear up the envelope material and drive the embedded, Class I protostar on its way to become a disk-only, Class II T Tauri star. Here we propose to obtain a homogeneous ALMA 13CO and C18O survey of all southern and equatorial FUors in order to resolve and image the structure and kinematics of gaseous material surrounding our targets. Our aim is to locate the source of the CO emission and, using radiative transfer codes, derive physical parameters of the envelopes. Our results will enable us to verify the evolutionary scenarios on the dispersal of the envelopes around young stars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
